title: 115_s2278
content: The "State Offices of Rural Health Reauthorization Act of 2018" allows grants to State Offices of Rural Health for improving healthcare in rural areas, with a requirement for matching funds from the State office involved. The Act requires non-Federal contributions equal to $3 for each $1 of Federal funds provided in the grant. The Secretary can waive or reduce this requirement if it limits the State office's ability to fulfill its purpose. Non-Federal contributions can be in cash or in kind, excluding Federal Government-provided amounts or services. Recipients of a grant under subsection (a) must use the funds for maintaining a clearinghouse for rural health information, coordinating state activities related to rural health care, and identifying and providing assistance for federal and state programs. The Secretary may only grant funds to a State office of rural health if they agree to provide an annual budget of at least $150,000. The grant cannot be used for providing healthcare or conducting activities already funded by the Federal government within the State. The State office of rural health can use grants for various purposes such as purchasing medical equipment, ambulances, or real property, and carrying out activities related to a certificate of need. Additionally, the grant can be used for maintaining the office of rural health and recruiting health professionals for rural areas. The State office of rural health can use grants for various purposes such as purchasing medical equipment, ambulances, or real property, and carrying out activities related to a certificate of need. The Secretary may impose a limit of no more than 15 percent on indirect costs claimed by the recipient of the grant. Reports must be submitted to the Secretary containing required information on activities carried out under this section. The State office of rural health must submit an application to the Secretary to receive a grant, containing necessary agreements and information. Payments will not be made for subsequent fiscal years if noncompliance is found. Authorization of appropriations is required for grant-making purposes. For grant-making purposes, $12,500,000 is authorized annually from 2018 to 2022. The appropriated amounts will remain available until expended.
